data.title: 23 famous faces from Grimsby and Cleethorpes
data.meta_description: The New Year is almost upon us – and we’re wanting to inspire you in 2020
data.text:
The New Year is almost upon us – and we’re wanting to inspire you in 2020.

GrimsbyLive are noting 23 famous or well-known people from Grimsby and Cleethorpes who have made us proud.

From a world record winner to an award-winning actress, maybe someone on our list could inspire you to do something amazing in 2020!

*Just to note, this list does not include every famous face from our area. However, all others not featured on this short list of 23 are also appreciated for their incredible talents.

Kevin and Joanne Clifton

Dancing-duo Kevin and Joanne Clifton have been waltzing around our TV screens since 2013 and 2014 respectively.

The Waltham-born dancers jived, tangoed and cha-cha-cha'd their way through childhood at their parents, dance school, Cliftons Dance Academy.

Initially partnering with each other, the brother-sister duo were taught ballroom and Latin before moving onto more and more dances until almost all were covered.

Kevin, 37, selected Latin as his primary dance style, while Joanne, 36, choose ballroom as to not directly compete against her older brother.

Moving forward, Joanne became a household name after winning Strictly Come Dancing in 2016 with her BBC sport presenter partner Ore Oduba.

And Kevin from Grimsby followed suit by winning Strictly 2018 with dance partner Stacey Dooley.

Kevin and Joanne are performing in Burn the Floor 2020 at Grimsby Auditorium in May. Click here to order your tickets.

Rochenda Sandall

She plays ruthless crime boss Lisa McQueen in the BBC’s hit police corruption series Line of Duty but actress Rochenda Sandall’s first ever role was a world away.

Her acting stage debut was as a nun in Sister Act II at her local school in Barton-upon-Humber.

But the Grimsby-born actress could have taken an altogether different path after she became an accomplished dancer under the guidance of Strictly star Kevin Clifton's parents in Grimsby.

Throughout her school years, Rochenda, who grew up in Goxhill, attended Cliftons Dance Academy, owned by Kevin's parents Judy and Keith Clifton.

It wasn’t until she was 18 that she took her first foray into acting at Baysgarth School’s musical production Sister Act II in Barton.

Rochenda now lives in London and is dating Game of Thrones star Mark Stanley, who played the ranger Grenn.

Patrick Wymark

Actor Patrick Wymark, born Patrick Carl Cheeseman, was a stage, film and television actor.

The Cleethorpes-born actor attended St Mary's Catholic School and Wintringham Boys' Grammar School in Grimsby, before joining the Royal Navy and serving as a midshipman in the Mediterranean.

Following this, Patrick studied English at University College London, where he joined the university’s dramatic society.

His acting career began with Shakespearean roles, including Dogberry in Much Ado About Nothing, Stephano in The Tempest, Marullus in Julius Caesar and Bottom in A Midsummer Night's Dream.

In television, Patrick was best known for his role as the machiavellian businessman John Wilder in the twin drama series The Plane Makers and The Power Game - broadcast between 1963 to 1969.

And his film appearances include Children of the Damned (1964), Operation Crossbow (1965), Repulsion (1965), Where Eagles Dare (1968), Witchfinder General (1968), Battle of Britain (1969), Doppelgänger (1969), The Blood on Satan's Claw (1970) and Cromwell (1970).

Patrick suddenly died in Melbourne, Australia, on October 20 1970, aged 44, of a heart attack in the hotel room in which he way staying.

Lisa George

Lisa George is best known for playing Beth Tinker in Coronation Street since 2011.

The 49-year-old, from Grimsby, has also been in Emmerdale, Casualty, Holby City, The Bill and Stanton Blues.

She was confirmed as the sixth contestant in this year's Dancing on Ice line-up, and announced her involvement on ITV’s Lorraine.

She revealed how she wanted to join Dancing On Ice 2020 to coincide with her 50th birthday.

Lisa told Lorraine: “I haven’t been on the ice for 40 years. Yesterday was my first session on the ice. It was good, I really enjoyed it, I didn’t fall.

“I was a bit scared, I was quite nervous, I can’t believe I’m 50 next year and I just thought: ‘If I don’t do this now, I’m never going to have the chance to do it again."

Julie Peasgood

Actress Julie Peasgood is perhaps most well known for her role as Fran Pearson in TV soap Brookside.

The 63-year-old, from Cleethorpes, later played Jo Steadman in Emmerdale in 1997 and Jacqui Hudson in Hollyoaks from 2001 to 2002.

She attended Grimsby’s Wintringham School.

Julie started to do voice overs in the 1980s, and has voiced hundreds of television and radio adverts.

She is most recognised for her 1990s advert for Bird's Eye Frozen Peas, and in 2003, Peasgood was known as the "queen of the ad voice overs”.

Thomas Turgoose

Actor Thomas Turgoose played Shaun in This is England, a British drama centred on a young skinhead in 1983.

He landed the lead role when he was 13-years-old, and went onto star in This is England 86, 88 and 90.

The 27-year-old also appeared in season 7 premiere of Games of Thrones as a Lannister soldier.

And last year, he wed his fiancée Charlotte Revell in a New Year's Eve ceremony.

Freddie Frinton

English comedian Freddie Frinton, born Frederick Bittiner Coo, is primarily remembered for his 1963 TV comedy sketch Dinner for One.

The actor, who was born on Hainton Avenue, Grimsby in 1909, became a household name in Northwestern European countries where Dinner for One was most popular.

He first performed Dinner for One in Blackpool in 1945 and due to having to pay a royalty each time he performed the sketch, Freddie bought the rights to it in the 1950s.

Some years later, he starred in TV sitcom Meet the Wife as the plumber husband.

The successful series proved popular among The Beatles who mention it in their song 'Good Morning Good Morning' in the line "It's time for tea and Meet the Wife".

Freddie, who is buried in the City of Westminster Cemetery, London, died suddenly from a heart attack aged 59.

Keeley Donovan

BBC North weather woman Keeley Donovan, from Tetney , started her broadcasting career at age 15, presenting for Channel 7 Television - now Estuary TV.

The former Humberston Academy and Franklin College student currently works as a BBC weather presenter for TV and radio stations in the North of England.

She married follow BBC presenter Johnny I'Anson on June 25, 2018.

Bernie Taupin

Lyricist and singer Bernie Taupin is best known for his long-term collaboration with Elton John.

He was born in a farmhouse in Anwick but spent most of his childhood in Owmby-by-Spital, near Market Rasen.

In 1967, Bernie answered an advert for talent in the New Musical Express by Liberty Records, and by happy coincidence, Elton John answered the same advert.

Neither Bernie nor Elton passed the audition for Liberty Records.

It was when Elton told a Liberty Records representative he could not write lyrics that he was handed a sealed envelope from the pile of people submitting lyrics - it contained poems by Bernie.

Following this, the duo collaborated on more than thirty albums to date.

Rod Temperton

"'Cause this is thriller. Thriller night."

Songwriter, musician and record producer Rod Temperton wrote several songs performed by Michael Jackson, including 'Thriller', 'Rock with You', and 'Off the Wall'.

The Cleethorpes -born man was R&B, funk and disco band Heatwave's main songwriter and keyboardist in the 1970s - their hit songs include 'Boogie Nights' and 'Always and Forever'.

In 1991, Rod won a Grammy Award for his work on 'Birdland', from Quincy Jone's album 'Back on the Block'.

Rod died from a "brief aggressive battle with cancer" on October 5, 2016.

Brenda Fisher

Back in 1951, Grimsby's Brenda Fisher broke the woman's world record for swimming the English Channel.

The long-distance swimmer, who was born in Scartho in 1927, started swimming at aged nine, initially as a speed swimmer.

It was in 1951 when Brenda swam across The English Channel from France to England, completing in a new record women's time - 12 hours and 42 minutes.

The previous women's record was secured one year earlier by Florance Chadwick with a time of 13 hours 20 minutes.

Brenda went on to win the 29-mile (47 kilometre) River Nile swim in 1956, and the 32-mile (51 kilometre) Lake Ontario swim from Niagara to Toronto with a time of 18 hours and 50 minutes.

One year later, now in 1957, Brenda attempted the Lake Ontario swim again and retired with a time of 12 hours and 43 minutes.

She published her biography Blonde In Deep Water, written by journalist Lucy Wood, in 2015.

Most recently, in 2016, Brenda appeared on BBC's Flog It! to sell her Clarice Cliff 'inspiration' vase, and in 2018, she appeared on Antiques Roadshow with her collection of swimming memorabilia.

Ella Henderson

Grimsby’s Ella Henderson was a favourite to win X-Factor in 2012, when she was just aged 16.

Despite not winning, Ella was given a recording contract by Simon Cowell’s label Syco.

She had a number one single, Ghost, and a number one album, Chapter One.

But after a brief spell at the top of the charts, Ella slipped into obscurity after being dropped by Simon Cowell’s record label.

But at aged 23, Ella is now back singing and has launched her first recording in years, an EP called Glorious.

Speaking as she launched her new EP, she said: "Everyone thinks I went into a hole... never to return. It's been too long.

"A lot of my life as a teenager was mental. There were moments of self-doubt and insecurity and I'd be lying if I said I woke up every day happy.”

Guy Martin

Guy Martin was born in Grimsby in November 1981 before moving further out into Northern Lincolnshire.

He is best known as a motorcycle racer turned television presenter of engineering-based projects, fronting whole series such as Our Guy In India and Speed With guy Martin. He has also written three books about his life.

He started racing in 1998, debuting on road circuits at the Isle of Man TT events in 2004, where he gained 17 podium finishes.

Guy works in Grimsby as a lorry mechanic.

Arthur Drewry

Between 1955 and 1961, Grimsby-born Arthur Drewry, who was born in 1891 and died in 1961, served as the fifth FIFA president.

He also served in several other football administration posts such as chairman of The Football Association and president of The Football League.

However his fruitful football administration career started at Grimsby Town where he served as a director.

It was his father-in-law, who was Grimsby Town's chairman, who helped Arthur secure this position, which later became a role he would take up.

In 1953, Arthur was appointed a Commander of Order of the British Empire (CBE).

Patricia Hodge

Actress Patricia Hodge, from Cleethorpes, made her West End debut in 1972 before starring in BBC sitcom Miranda between 2009 to 2015.

The 73-year-old, who attended Wintringham Grils' Grammar School, now Oasis Academy Wintringham, stared in the film Betrayal (1983), the TV series Rumpole of the Bailey (1978 to 1992), the TV film Hotel du Lac (1986), among more.

She received a Best Actress BAFTA TV Award nomination as well as two Laurence Olivier Award nominations for Best Actress in a Musical, and won the 2000 Laurence Olivier Award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in the play Money.

Sir John Hurt

The actor John Hurt played roles in more than 120 blockbuster films, including Elephant Man, Alien and Harry Potter - as well as numerous stage and television roles over six decades.

He died aged 77 after a battle with pancreatic cancer, which he revealed he had been diagnosed with in 2015.

Sir John grew up in Blundell Avenue, Cleethorpes, and spent many an afternoon watching Grimsby Town play. He was also a regular at the outdoor swimming pool in the resort.

He was born in Derbyshire but moved to Lincolnshire and enrolled at Grimsby Art School, now Grimsby Institute, before winning a scholarship to study for an Art Teacher’s Diploma at Central St Martin’s College, London.

Receiving an Honorary Doctorate Of Arts at the University of Lincoln in 2013, Sir John reflected on his formative years in the area.

He said: “My most lasting and life-long impression from Lincolnshire was at Grimsby Art School and Peter Todd, the principal, who was very influential in my thinking.

“He encouraged people to think for themselves and encouraged every bit of creativity he could.

“But I’d really decided, in my mind, I wanted to act at the age of nine doing school plays. You have to remember though this was 1949, just after the war, and I had no idea how you went about becoming an actor. But the idea just kept coming back to me and when I suggested it everyone said ‘no, it’s insecure’.

“After the war, two things were really sought after and they were security and respectability.

“But I constantly thought of acting and was going into a state of trauma because I knew I wanted to do something else. Fortunately, in my case, it did work out. It doesn’t for everyone.”

Sir John was knighted in 2015 for his services to drama.

Lloyd Griffith

Comedian and Sky Sports presenter Lloyd Griffith, kick-started his comedy career on BBC Radio 1 Comedy Lounge in 2014.

The 36-year-old from Grimsby has also appeared on Sky TV, BBC and Comedy Central shows The Sweat Small Stuff, Rugby's Funniest Moments and Drunk History.

Lloyd, who supports Grimsby Town and covers some of their games on BBC Radio Humberside, has announced a new stand-up tour for 2020 with three local dates.

The (still) aspiring goalkeeper has included three Grimsby dates for March 4, 5 and 6, at the Docks Beers brewery's new 300 capacity venue; which opens early next year.

Peter Collinson

Director Peter Collinson was born in Cleethorpes in 1936.

He is best known for the Italian Job, starring Michale Caine, Noel Coward and Benny Hill. The screen classic celebrates its 50th anniversary this year.

He also directed The Long Day's Dying and Up The Junction, both in 1968.

He died in Los Angeles in December 1980 at the age of just 44.

Shaun Pulfrey

After being turned down on Dragons' Den, Grimsby's Shaun Pulfrey went on to develop a £23 million business.

It was in 2007 when Shaun pitched his detangling hairbrushes, now commonly known as Tangle Teezer, to dragons Peter Jones, Duncan Bannatyne, James Caan and Deborah Meaden, who each rejected the opportunity to invest in his business.

He offered them 15 per cent in his Tangle Teezer brand for £80,000.

During his Dragons' Den appearance, James Caan said the Tangle Teezer is a "waste of time", while Duncan Bannatyne said he wanted to "pull his hair out".

When Shaun's Dragons' Den episode aired, the Tangle Teezer website crashed due to an increase in demand with 1,500 orders placed in the matter of minutes.

To date, Tangle Teezer has an annual turn over of approximately £23.4 million.

David Ross

Co-founder of Carphone Warehouse David Ross, from Grimsby, was one of the riches people in the UK when his business peaked in 2008.

In 2008, American business magazine Forbes ranked him as number 843 in the world's richest billionaires, with a net worth of approximately $1.4 billion.

He is the grandson of Carl Ross, who established Ross Group and obtained the Great Grimsby Coal, Salt and Tanning Company, known as Cosalt.

Ross was 16-years-old when his father sent him to work on an Algeria building site, which he said was "a defining moment because it was so bad I had to get away from it and be able to control my destiny".

Helen Fospero

Best-known for her presenting roles on Daybreak, Lorraine and GMTV, Helen Fospero was one of the first journalists to be recruited by Sky Television in the 1980s.

The Cleethorpes woman, who is a former Whitgift School student, is currently working for BBC's The One Show and Watchdog.

Helen played Lucinda Towne in Black Mirror's 'The National Anthem' and played herself in one episode of BBC Two's How TV Ruined Your Life.

Duncan McKenzie

Footballer Duncan McKenzie, from Grimsby, played as a striker in the Football League for Everton, Leeds United, Chelsea, Nottingham Forest, Mansfield Town and Blackburn Rovers in the 1970s.

After starting his career with Nottingham Forest, he was later loaned to Mansfield Town in exchange for emergency goalkeeper Dave Hollins.

Following his football career, the now 69-year-old worked as a newspaper columnist, and replaced Danny Baker on Radio Five's 6-0-6 programme.
